titleStmt.title: Washing Clothes Harran

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.

spanGrp.span: In the past washing clothes; as for the washing of clothes in the past, there was nothing, there were no washing machines. There were no devices.
There were no devices. — There were no washing machines. When I was young, the same age as Sumayya, We used to bring large barrels at my family’s place.
They were made, let’s say, by people who were craftsmen. They cut them in half and made them very robust so they wouldn’t fall apart.
They had also smoothed the edges. Haven’t they would cut these barrels in half?
So that they are not sharp for the hands; to prevent the hands from getting cut.
They also bent the edges to ensure they wouldn’t harm anyone.
They had also attached one or two handles in order that it could be carried. We would bring it, that half-barrel; and it would be dragged, this large half-barrel.
It could hold approximately, let’s say, twelve cans; the large barrel could take that amount. This one holds 6 canisters. I mean a ‘can’ (tnike) and a ‘canister’ (dabbiyye) are the same thing.
We would fill it with a hose. We used to bring it; in the past, there was (enough) water.
The water didn’t come through pumps or anything like that. It was tap water.
We would place the hose and bring it to the kitchen. What was the kitchen? It was just a place where we cooked. The fire, the fire for eating and food.
Or for the bread. We used to heat the water. It wasn’t like our kitchens today. It was called a kitchen, but it was made of clay.
It was made of clay. — Let’s say it was made of clay and had a chimney. The chimney would draw the smoke.
We would gather firewood when it rained, when it was winter. We would go and collect firewood; and my mother would tell us,
“Spread the firewood under the sun!” We would spread it out when it was winter, so it would dry, and then we would move it and gather it into bundles.
We would make a bundle, bring it inside the kitchen and leave it there, so we could use it for washing and cooking.
We would store it inside the kitchen until it was time for washing. We would bring the hose and fill a large pot; we filled it until it was completely full.
My older sister would say, “Let the fly drink from it!”
Why? She said, “Let the fly drink from it!” (meaning, let the pot fill up to the point where a fly could drink from its edge). She would tell me, “Fill your pot!”
“Let the fly drink from it!” means it should be filled all the way to the top. It means you should let it overflow.
“Don’t leave it as little like that! Let the fly drink from it!” (Implying the pot should be filled to the brim.) So, the fly can drink without drowning.
“Let the fly drink from it” is a saying which means, “Fill it up!” It implies filling something to the brim. And she would tell me, “Let the fly drink from it!”
I understand what she means when she says this, which is that I should fill it completely. It means I shouldn’t leave even an inch or about four fingers of space empty.
When there was something missing (as you say), “Should I fill it? I’ll fill it that it will overflow.”
After that, I would get up and start heating it. I would set up the fire and keep on fanning the flames.
Until I see it starting to heat up, then we would say, “My sister! The water is heated, come!”
Then, the one who wants to take a bath comes and fills the bucket, using a bowl to scoop and fill the bucket.
Then they would take, let’s say, we had a large room which contained something like a bathroom.
There, we put a curtain next to the door like this. There were no real bathrooms in the past, there was no bathroom (in the house), no!
The bathroom was the room where we would also sit, sleep, eat, drink. And we also also bathed in it.
We would do everything in it, except for relieving ourselves. We used the living room for everything.
Everything was in one place, in one single room. And since the stove was set up there, a stove for coal or for wood.
Since it was installed inside that room, we had to come into the room where the stove was.
We used to light the stove, bring the kettles or a bucket to scoop the water; and we also bring the soap.
There was no shampoo, meaning the things used for bathing today were not available back then.
There was only the traditional soap, which people would buy; it came in bags.
Let’s say they brought it in a kind of sacks. But that soap was so hard that it even did not dissolve the hair which remained without sheen.
